summary: During the Great Depression, ex-boxer James J. Braddock (Russell Crowe) works as a day laborer until his former manager Joe Gould (Paul Giamatti) offers him a one-time slot against a rising young contender. After he wins a shocking upset, Braddock goes back into the ring full time, against the wishes of his frightened wife, Mae (Renée Zellweger). Dubbed "The Cinderella Man" for his rags-to-riches story, Braddock sets his sights on the defending champion, the fearsome Max Baer (Craig Bierko).

Ron Howard's historical drama Cinderella Man (2005) is an inspiring boxing biopic about James J. Braddock demonstrating Howard's absolute empathy for a poor man pushed to his limit who does not give up. Russell Crowe portrays "Cinderella Man" James J. Braddock, who inspires the nation when America needed it most during The Great Depression. Cliff Hollingsworth and Akiva Goldsman's story and script fill you with American pride and motivation. Their words are heartfelt and subtle with earnest pleas for the plight of the impoverished and disenfranchised.

Howard incredibly recreates America during 1929-1935 with astonishing detail from his production designers Wynn Thomas, Peter Grundy, Dan Yarhi. Howard's view of America during The Great Depression is bleak making this film a harrowing watch. However, Cinderella Man is uplifting as you see a desperate fight to feed his family in a genuinely moving picture about a heroic Depression era pugilist.

Russell Crowe finds real heart in depicting James J. Braddock. His perseverance of will and dedication to his family make Braddock very likable. You want to root for the underdog, but Crowe truly invests you in this man of little luck and devastating circumstances. His accent, mannerisms, body language, and fighting stance all change in a revelation of acting for Cinderella Man. Crowe has wonderful chemistry with the eternal beauty and kind-hearted Renée Zellweger as James J. Braddock's long suffering wife Mae Braddock. Her patience, bravery, desperation, uncertainty, and love are all apparent from Zellweger's humanistic performance. I just adore Zellweger and she is remarkably convincing in these period dramas.

I really enjoy Paul Giamatti screaming out encouraging coaching advice as Joe Gould. I could watch him yell supportive statements at Crowe for 9 hours if that's all Cinderella Man was, but he's very affectionate and real alongside Russell Crowe. Craig Bierko is monstrous as the behemoth boxer Max Baer. His brutality and stature precede his shocking behavior. Paddy Considine is likable as Braddock's dock friend Mike Wilson. You despise Bruce McGill as boxing magnate Jimmy Johnston. Rance Howard and Clint Howard get neat cameos as an announcer and referee too because Ron Howard is such a kind family man.

Ron Howard's direction is peerless and impressive as ever. He clearly gives you the facts of Braddock's life, yet depicts his unreal tragedies and triumphs with a sympathetic eye. Howard directs movies to make you cry and appreciate all you have in life. Cinderella Man has stayed with me ever since I first saw it. Revisiting it has been just as inspiring. It's 144 minutes of brutal Depression era suffering resulting in an astonishing underdog story. Every boxing match is intense, fast, and exciting up there with Rocky and Raging Bull's fights. Ron Howard continues to deliver excellent filmmaking with creative storytelling with his influential auteur style.

I love how masterful Howard's direction is on a technical level. Slowing down a shot for a brief moment to make punches more dramatic. Anthony J. Ciccolini III and Tony Volante's sound choices are incredible as every punch sounds like a brick hitting Crowe. The punches sound realistic, but heavy. The rapid fire hits to the stomach and head reverberates in your head like an earthquake. Daniel P. Hanley and Mike Hill's editing cuts you from blow to blow with professional precision. Everything is sleek and mature with gentle conversations with few cuts and thrilling boxing matches flying by in brief moments.

Salvatore Totino's cinematography is gorgeous with wide shots outside and stunning close-ups for intimate moments. His slick camera pans around the ring are as cool as his shots under the fighters' head and guts for quick flurries of punches. All the dark moody lighting is impressive on its own merits too. Ron Howard uses the camera to convey to audiences that you can improve and you should feel sympathy for boxers' wives. Cinderella Man is pure classic boxing cinema.

Thomas Newman's score is really understated and mature. His composition for Cinderella Man is subtle and cushions hard times with soft symphonies of sympathy. Daniel Orlandi's costumes look period accurate and fit effortlessly into The Depression Era in dock hand clothes, boxing uniforms, and post-flapper dresses. I'm very impressed by Burton J. LeBlanc and David LeRoy Anderson's breathtaking and rough make-up that looks like the boxers actually were hurt.

In all, Cinderella Man is a magnificent display of filmmaking prowess and knowledge from iconic American director Ron Howard. With legendary performances from Crowe and Zellweger, how can you not be touched by Cinderella Man's inspiring story? Watch Cinderella Man and be amazed.

Very rarely do you get a portrait of hero this masterfully created. Russell Crowe stars as Jim Braddock, a promising young boxer who fell on harder times due to injury and a string of bad fights.  He loses his license and descends into abject poverty during the depression.  A lucky break gets him an exhibition fight which he wins, and he manages a comeback that eventually gets him a title shot against heavyweight champ Max Baer.  Crowe is really quite good in the lead role, as is Paul Giamatti as his manager.  The final half hour of this film, which is the fight against Baer, is really quite thrilling.  The problem is that it takes two hours to get there, and that's an hour too long.  This is a fairly straightforward riches to rags to riches story, yet we spend a lot of time in the rags portion bludgeoning the same few themes to brutal death.  Like a lot of Ron Howard's work, this is a decent, competent, totally unimaginative film that I really did not need to spend this much time with.
I'm from outside Philadelphia, so if I find a boxing movie that is somehow more inspirational than Rocky, that is really saying something.

Cinderella Man stars Russell Crowe as Jim Braddock, a boxer on-the-rise until a broken hand and the Great Depression turn his world upside-down. Forced to work the docks to provide for his family, Braddock gets a second chance when his former trainer/promoter (played by Paul Giamatti in an Academy Award nominated performance) offers him a spot as a replacement fighter. This movie is based off of a true story, and, for the most part, the facts hold up. Whenever I watch a movie based on reality, I like to look into the real story to see what was exaggerated for the sake of film. Apparently, the biggest exaggeration in this movie was the portrayal of the "villain" boxer Max Baer, who in real-life was considered a gentleman instead of the crazy cliche we got on screen. My absolute favorite part of this movie was the film score. Thomas Newman, the mastermind behind the music for the Shawshank Redemption, understands emotions and creates music that matches the tone of this film perfectly. The performances from Crowe and Giamatti were also great. However, this felt like a big soap-opera. When things went south, not a scene went by when we didn't get a lingering shot of one or more characters having a case of the sads with somber music in the background. It was really overkill in my opinion. Ron Howard has directed his fair-share of emotional movies, but he really went overboard on the emotional turmoil, which is hard considering what a tough time it really was. I understand that this is a great story of a true Cinderella Man representing overcoming tough obstacles during a low point in American history, but with movies like Rocky, Million Dollar Baby, and even Ali, Cinderella Man falls short as a sports film great. The 2-hour-plus runtime drags along, forcing you to endure the melodrama longer than you'd like. Is it a bad movie? No. Forgettable? Absolutely.

A great movie that performs as a boxing epic and doubles as an insightful analysis of Depression-era America and the family structure of the time.

Grit and desperation are key factors to many boxing careers, often the ones that are bright sparks as opposed to long flames. Braddock's story is one like that and this films knows it. 

The role was perfect for Crowe and the supporting cast are on top form too. Giamatti and Zellweger were also very well cast and the film brought out their talents accordingly. Its well-written and there's some strong dialogue in there that's just occasional enough to be memorable- perfect for a boxing film.

There's not too much emphasis on the fight scenes here- they are well-done but they are also there to further the rest of the story, as it should be- something many boxing movies seem to forget. 

With most films I'm understanding of the criticism that they receive- I may not agree, but I can see the points being made. I think its worth mentioning with this film though that the majority of criticism put to it is fairly unconvincing. 

Firstly, the criticism that this is a fairytale story- indeed it is, its no secret, there's lines in the film referring to how such moments are not as one might imagine them to be. Its certainly got idealistic elements- I don't see what is wrong with these things, in fact, a good boxing movie almost always has them- while it may take notes, this film is not trying to be another Raging Bull.

Secondly, there's criticism that can generally be applied to most boxing movies- nothing specific to this film, its unsubtle and overly-sentimental for example- again, how is this not exactly what everyone expected? Its very-well done and it was convincing, for me anyway.

Any great depression-era film nowadays seems to be slaughtered for its unrealstic depiction of the times, as if, every film is supposed to contain the power that The Grapes of Wrath did- this film does a fine job in showing the circumstances for Braddock's family- that's what this is about after all, there's a great feeling of time and place here and I don't care how superficial it may be in the grand scheme of things because the movie experience itself is genuine- something Ron Howard is great at creating.

I do get some of the criticism though- there is indeed a lack of personality within Braddock's depiction here, its too 'stereotypical nice-guy' but this film stars Russell Crowe so what on Earth did you expect going in? That criticism holds up more with the film's depiction of Baer- indeed it is far too 'stereotypical bad-guy boxer' and it was pretty unnecessary.

The reason Cinderella Man is great is because it combines elements of Rocky and Raging Bull without chatting into the same ultra-dark and brutal territory but instead tackling its own form of dramatic territory that emphasises various characters instead of just The Cinderella Man himself, as it's key focus is on boxer James J. Braddock but it also explores the world of boxing and the media influence, as well as how James J. Braddock influenced the people around him, and frankly Ron Howard's deep and meaningful direction combined with Cliff Hollingsworth and Akiva Goldsman's insightful screenplay ensures that the story is an in depth look at the world of boxing and how The Cinderella Man influenced it. 
And one thing that's important about a biopic covering a famous sports figure is that it has to be a film which has the heart of a true sports film, and due to the technical achievement of fine cinematography, strong editing and a good musical score, viewers are really easily able to get a feel for how the atmosphere within the boxing ring projects emotions into its characters. Cinderella Man finds a fine balance between exploring boxing and exploring its titular figure, which makes it an equally impressive boxing drama and biopic, and in my opinion it's more balanced than the boxing classic Raging Bull.
And powered by Ron Howard's strong direction, the cast have plenty to work with.
Russell Crowe makes a strong lead, and another good effort in his second collaboration with Ron Howard biographical film. They work really well together in characterising important historical figures as we learned before from A Beautiful Mind, and their effort on Cinderella Man enforces that, because it's another impressive and insightful biopic, even if the filmmakers have taken liberties with certain facts, again. Russell Crowe creates a strong Irish accent without going over the top and he gives a strong performance again.
But all the cast members are overshadowed by Paul Giamatti, which is a phrase I never thought I'd say. Paul Giamatti is unarguably at his absolute finest in Cinderella Man. His articulation of a Jersey accent is one of his finest talents he uses, but his strongest is really convincing me that he wasn't Paul Giamatti. I mean, he's so swift and perfect with his line delivery and so sophisticated and quick witted and street smart. It just seems like an alternative persona to Paul Giamatti as opposed to the characters he commonly finds himself playing, such as idiotic comedic characters like in Big Fat Liar. He's suave and quick and just excellent in The Cinderella Man, and there are so many appropriate words to describe his fine performance, but it can be summarised by the fact that he earned an Academy Award nomination for his performance.
Renee Zellwegger is also at some of her strongest dramatic work in Cinderella Man without playing a character that falls into a melodramatic routine because she has an emotional grip on the dramatics in the story and uses her tenacity as an actress to back up Russell Crowe every step of the way as well as holding her own on screen. She fits the role really well and uses good voice articulation.
Although Cinderella Man's portrayal of Max Baer is inaccurate, I feel like he is a clever combination of the media's depiction of him at the time and the person he actually is. There's one moment in Cinderella Man where he says to James J. Braddock that he doesn't want him in the ring because he doesn't want I to injure him, and I believed it. Even afterwords when he played it all off as a joke for the media, I still believed it. I believed that Max Baer was a good man and a hell of a boxer even though he was aggressive, and Craig Bierko did an excellent job in the role in terms of acting and mimicking Max Baer's fighting style. And he even blends acting and boxing together well because he plays to the public image well as well as making the effort to bring out the best fighter in James J. Braddock, and even after the fight he has the decency to touch gloves. If you know what Max Baer is really about and look at him at the right angle, you can really appreciate Craig Bierko's efforts, because he does a strong job.

So Cinderella Man is a powerful story which is constructed well and acted excellently, even if it is a predictable one.
